intro: Semecarpus annamensis, commonly known as the Annam chestnut, is a deciduous tree native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Sapindaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The tree produces woody fruits that contain a single, hard-shelled seed. It is often found in tropical and subtropical forests, growing in moist, well-drained soils. The plant has been used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
